{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3092468,"name":"","username":"protocol_1903","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/b9bd4f/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-10-27T16:20:19.354Z","cooked":"

Hey there! I’m working on a capstone project to create a t-shirt cannon robot, and I need some help figuring out the ideal velocity for the t-shirt when it exits the cannon. I could use normal kinematics to figure out how fast we need it, but the air resistance is a large enough factor that it’s not negligable. What speeds has everyone else been shooting theirs at?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2022-10-27T16:20:19.354Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":318,"reads":230,"readers_count":229,"score":1661.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":416665,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-ideal-velocity","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54334,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-ideal-velocity/416665/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3092474,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-27T16:51:13.620Z","cooked":"

How far do you want it to go? Shooting into the stands from a baseball field is different than shooting into a parade crowd. In any event, if you can hit 60mph that should cover the long distance case – just have a way to turn it down in more intimate settings.

This seems like a great use for the projectile calculator in my AMB Robotics Calculator

https://ambcalc.com/projectile

It will handle the kinematics as well as air resistance. The drag equations were designed for spheres, but should work sufficiently for short cylinders like a rolled t-shirt. You can guess at the drag coefficient, or use the experimental method outlined in the docs to find it. Set the avg. spin to zero to neglect lift from the magnus effect, which you won’t have with a cylinder.

neglect lift from the magnus effect, which you won’t have with a cylinder.
